content:
Do some checks:

Firewall: Access Firewall - it might be the defaulton computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus prgram. Set up Thunderbird program as 'allowed' so nothing gets blocked. Confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program.

VPN: Check computer for a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and I have come across some peopl who did not realise one had been enabled. Switch off VPN (or create split tunnelling and set it up for Thunderbird to use). Gmail does not like VPN as it atempts to hide your IP address, so gmail decides you might be hacker so it auto blocks access. Confirm VPN is switched off

Password: Logon to webmail account via a browser to see emails. If this works then you know the password is correct.

In Thunderbird Account Hub Not sure what version of Thunderbird you are using but if up to date then check to see if Account Hub is disabled.

  • Settings > General
  • For 'Account Hub'
  • uncheck/do not select: 'Create accounts in the new Account Hub'

Check the previously saved passwords for the email address - both incoming and outgoing are removed.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • There should be two lines for the email address - select them and click on 'Remove'
  • click on 'Close'

Then create account.

  • Menu app icon > New Account > Email
  • Enter Name, email address, password and select checkbox to remember password.
  • Click on 'Continue'

Thunderbird attempts to locate server settings. It knows most but not all. By default, it usually looks for imap, so if you want pop protocol then you will need to reselect it. If it does not locate correct server settings - click on 'Configure Manually'

IMAP Server Settings:

  • Server name: mail.gilanet.com
  • Port: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authetication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address

POP Server Settings:

  • Server name: mail.gilanet.com
  • Port: 995
  • Connection SEcurity: SSL/TLS
  • Authetication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address

SMTP Server Settings:

  • Server name: smtp.gilanet.com
  • If you use Port 465
  • Then use Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • If you use Port: 587
  • then use Connection SEcurity: STARTTLS
  • Authetication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: full email address
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Maybe proxy? Go to TB menu > Settings and search for proxy. Click the 'Settings' button under 'Connection'. Try switching to System or No. If it still doesn't work, ssee if anything relevant shows up in the Error Console:

- press Ctrl-Shift-J

- click the Trash can on the upper left to clear the console

- make sure 'Errors' is the only category selected

- click the 'Get Messages' (cloud) icon at the top of the Folder column

- if there are errors, R. click > Copy Message or Copy all Messages > paste here
creator: siffemoz

content: In your French Thunderbird version go to Affichage > Dossiers and check ✔︎ En-tête du panneau des dossiers I agree with you that this settings is well hidden and it took me while to remember...

content: you can export an addressbook, but (to my knowledge) not a distribution list. you can import the full addressbook with tools>import>import from a file and follow the links for addressbook. when you get to last menu, it will offer several addressbook formats to import. To know which one to use, check the profile of old laptop's thunderbird. if there is an abook.sqlite file, then on new computer, import the abook.sqlite file. If not, then import the abook.mab file (which is the older version)..

content:
Troubleshooting is a real can of worms. but my first suggestion to everyone is to look at what else is monitoring the disk for updates and eliminate that. Things like streaming backups, cloud sync of the storage location and antivirus all have a role to play normally in accessing your disk.

Generally Thunderbird stored your profile in ah hidden location accessed by the windows variable %adddata% some folk routinely change this location for various reasons and they frequently have issues with Third party applications that do not recognize the Thunderbird mail store as application data after the move.

content: It may be that thunderbird created a new profile during the update. try clicking help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles and click 'about:profiles' and on next screen you can click to browse other profiles. look in imapmail folder for IMAP account or mail folder for POP account. if you see that info in an inactive profile, that may be the one you want. click the launch button to verify. if it works, and if your account logs in, that would indicate that thunderbird had retained the password. You can retrieve it at settings>privacy&security

creator: reiring

content:
No one here really cares if it works on Outlook. One of the primary reasons things "just work" on Outlook is it opts for minimum security. Thunderbird opts for maximum, and the inconveniences that6 go along with that.

This error message you posted to this forum is clear. You can't use SSL/TLS with this server name because a valid certificate can not be obtained from the server to encrypt the connection. No amount of "it works with Outlook" will change that fact.

I looked at your providers web site but found exactly zero relevant details posted. Google offers settings on the support pages of just about every mail client, but the provider that determines what settings work does not publish them publicly. handy for the rest of us, good thing they have loyal paying customers to support their hubris.

What I do see from these settings you posted is you are connecting on Port 587. Port 587 is the standard, recommended port for sending email (SMTP submission) because it requires authentication and uses STARTTLS encryption to secure the connection. However a valid certificate can not be obtained from the server so by definition is can not work.

I tried testing the server on that port. https://www.immuniweb.com/ssl/optimum.net/ympAPJkt/ The test failed as the server was not accepting connections on that port, or port 465 which is an unencrypted connection. This usually means you live in the USA where providers routinely restrict you to sending mail only if you are connected using their service. My experience so far with this is this only happens in the USA. The recent explosion in the popularity of VPNs leads to issues where the mail server refuses to allow you to send mail as you are not connected with the ISP's service, but with the VPN. So I am guessing you have a shiny new VPN and your provider is refusing to play.

content:
I have exactly the same response as christ1.

I am guessing like many folk you simply do not understand what a mail client is or you would not be making the statements you are.

Thunderbird needs access to your gmail account to get mail, or contacts or calendars I really have no idea what you set up to sync. The next page of the authorization flow will show what exactly you are asking Thunderbird to access.

It is that simple. Google have set the oAuth protocol to be the authentication method to get mail, contacts and calendars and that screen is requesting you sign into Google to provide authentication to Google for Thunderbird to have access to your data for the purpose of doing it's job. The next page of the flow indicated exactly what data is to be accessed.

I would guess you have syncronised contact or calendars if you have removed the email, but all I can do is guess.

content:
The error console reports multiple errors when I try to only import messages. I tried importing all the settings and in this case the error console only reports this error:

Uncaught (in promise) NS_ERROR_FILE_NAME_TOO_LONG: Component returned failure code: 0x80520011 (NS_ERROR_FILE_NAME_TOO_LONG) [nsIFile.create] 

   _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:764    _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:765    _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:765    _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:765    _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:765    _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:765    _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:765    _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:765    _recursivelyCopyMsgFolder resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:765    _mergeLocalFolders resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:738    _importServersAndAccounts resource:///modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs:347
creator: tk982

content:
That source code is here https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/import/modules/ThunderbirdProfileImporter.sys.mjs Line 765 was last affected by changes in this bug https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1978987

However NS_ERROR_FILE_NAME_TOO_LONG is quite probably a very literal issue. Windows limits the length of a path to 260 characters approx. My guess is your folder structures is so deep that the copy fails because the path is just to long. Especially if you allow for the fact many profiles start somewhere around 80 of those characters from the root of the C: drive.

The error however can simply mean you do not have write access to the relevant disk area either through file contention(Your anti virus is often a culprit for this problem) or the drive being full so the error is that there is no space to the file and it bubbles up as a file length issue. This is a relatively generic JavaScript error. So google can help with ideas as to the cause and I do not mean just as it relates to Thunderbird.

You might also want to check your new installation does not have the system integration to allow Windows search to search mails allowed as that adds another duplicate layer of mail in lower down the folder tree. Mozmsgs folders with mozeml files. Individual file names are based on the email subject and are a prime source of the path becoming to long.
creator: MattAuSupport
